questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following statements is true regarding amenorrhoea?

options.a: MRKH syndrome is associated with secondary amenorrhoea
options.b: Primary amenorrhoea is seen in Turner syndrome
options.c: Primary amenorrhea is absence of menarche by 13 years
options.d: Secondary amenorrhea is absence of menses for 6 months

questions.explanation:
Primary amenorrhoea is seen in Turner syndrome Amenorrhoea is a symptom and not a disease entity. It refers to the absence of menstruation that 
can be physiological or pathological. Primary amenorrhea is defined as an absence of menstruation by the age of 15 years. At age 13 
years, if no menses have occurred and there is a complete absence of secondary sexual 
characteristics such as breast development, evaluation for primary amenorrhea should 
begin. Mullerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome), androgen insensitivity syndrome, and Turner 
syndrome present with primary amenorrhea. In Turner's syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis causes 
primary ovarian failure, resulting in hypogonadism and amenorrhea. Secondary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menses for 3 or more months or fewer than 9 
cycles per year after the establishment of regular menstrual cycles. Polycystic ovarian syndrome 
and hypothyroidism are associated with secondary amenorrhea. Pregnancy is the most common 
physiological cause of secondary amenorrhea.

questions.question:
Question 2: While evaluating a patient with secondary amenorrhoea, you administer her estrogen and 
progesterone. However, withdrawal bleeding is not seen. What is the likely site of lesion 
here?
questions.explanation:
The absence of withdrawal bleeding after the estrogen-progesterone challenge test points towards 
a local endometrial lesion. Estrogen–progesterone challenge test is indicated as an investigation in case of secondary 
amenorrhea. It depends on estrogen-primed endometrium being present in the uterus. Procedure: • Ethinyl estradiol 0.02 mg or conjugated equine estrogen 1.25 mg is to be taken daily for 25 days. • Medroxyprogesterone acetate 10 mg daily is added from day 15–25. • Alternately, one course of oral contraceptive pill is given and to observe whether withdrawal 
bleeding occurs or not. Results: • If there is no bleeding, a local endometrial lesion is present such as uterine synechiae. This is to 
be confirmed by HSG or hysteroscopy. • If withdrawal bleeding occurs, the endometrium is responsive but the endogenous estrogen 
production is inadequate. Hence, the defect lies in the ovary, hypothalamus, or pituitary. 560 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: The risk of Asherman syndrome is highest if D&C is done for  
.
questions.explanation:
The risk of developing Asherman syndrome is the highest if D&C is done for postpartum 
hemorrhage. This is because the postpartum uterus is larger and bulkier. Hence, a greater area of the uterine 
wall is curetted. This increases the risk of developing Asherman syndrome. Asherman syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of large areas of 
the endometrium. The treatment of Asherman syndrome is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following statements is true regarding oligomenorrhea?

options.c: Menstruation occurring at an interval of more than 30 days

questions.explanation:
Oligomenorrhoea can progress to develop into amenorrhoea. Oligomenorrhoea means infrequent, irregularly timed episodes of bleeding usually occurring at 
intervals of more than 38 days.

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient with uterine fibroids complains of frequent menstruation with an average cycle 
duration of 19-21 days. What is this menstrual irregularity called?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of polymenorrhoea, also known as epimenorrhea. It refers 
to frequent episodes of menstruation, usually occurring at intervals of 21 days or less. The definitions of various menstrual cycle irregularities are: Amenorrhoea refers to the absence of menstruation. Intermenstrual bleeding refers to occasional episodes of bleeding (usually not excessive) that 
occur between otherwise normal menstrual cycles. Hypomenorrhea refers to regularly timed cycles, but having scanty episodes of bleeding. Menorrhagia refers to regularly timed menstrual cycles with excessive bleeding (>80 mL in 
amount) and/or increased duration of flow (>8 days). Metrorrhagia refers to normal cyclical bleeding with superimposed irregularly timed episodes of 
bleeding. Menometrorrhagia refers to excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed and 
frequent intervals. Oligomenorrhea refers to infrequent, irregularly timed cycles with intervals of more than 38 days. Precocious menstruation refers to the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following statements is true regarding menorrhagia?

options.a: Heavy and regularly timed episodes of bleeding
options.c: Amount of bleeding greater than 50 ml
options.d: Duration of bleeding greater than 5 days

questions.explanation:
561 
Sold by @itachibot Menorrhagia is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding. Menorrhagia denotes regularly timed episodes of bleeding that are excessive in amount (>80 
mL) and/or duration of flow (>8 days). Nowadays, menorrhagia has been replaced by the term 
heavy menstrual bleeding. This is defined as greater than 80 mL per cycle, which will result in 
anemia if recurrent Investigations done in case of menorrhagia: • Complete blood count (CBC) - to rule out anemia and thrombocytopenia. • Coagulation studies are ordered only in case of clinical suspicion and correlation with CBC • Sonohysterography/Hysteroscopy - to diagnose endometrial polyps and fibroids • Endometrial biopsy - in case of suspected endometrial hyperplasia • Transvaginal ultrasound - supplements biopsy

questions.question:
Question 7: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. 
The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non-hormonal management 
has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Hormonal therapy is the next best step in the given scenario of menorrhagia that is unresponsive 
to non-hormonal therapy. Menorrhagia/heavy menstrual bleeding is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding, 
>80mL of blood loss, or >8 days of bleeding per menstrual period. It can be acute (<6 
months) or chronic (>6 months). It is managed as follows: • Medical - first line of treatment. • NSAIDs • Tranexamic acid • OCPs/progestogens - if non-hormonal management fails • Mirena IUCD • GnRH agonists • Blood transfusion, if required • Surgical - if medical management fails, depending on the diagnosis: • Endometrial ablation - hysteroscopic, TCRE, RITEA, microwave, NovaSure, etc (option B) • Uterine artery embolization (option A) • Uterine tamponade • Hysterectomy - if all minimally invasive methods fail (option D)

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is not a feature of menometrorrhagia?
questions.explanation:
Menometrorrhagia refers to menstrual bleeding at frequent intervals. 562 
Sold by @itachibot Menometrorrhagia means excessive, prolonged bleeding that occurs at irregularly timed and 
frequent intervals. It can be caused by cervical cancer and granulosa cell tumors.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient who had undergone a dilatation and curettage procedure comes to the clinic 6 
months later for a follow-up visit. She informs you that since the procedure, she has had 
scanty blood loss during menses which only lasts for 1-2 days. What is this pattern of bleeding 
called?
questions.explanation:
In the given clinical scenario, the pattern of bleeding is called hypomenorrhea. Hypomenorrhea 
along with a prior history of dilatation and curettage are suggestive of partial Asherman's 
syndrome. Hypomenorrhoea refers to regularly timed but scanty episodes of bleeding. It can be seen in: • Partial Asherman's syndrome - uterine synechiae, causing scarring • Oral contraceptive use • Perimenopausal age group

questions.question:
Question 10: A 36-year-old woman presents to the gynecology OPD with complaints of occasional bleeding 
PV between her usual menstrual cycles. Which of the following is true about her condition?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of intermenstrual bleeding, also known as metrorrhagia. 
Usually, this is scanty, and not excessive. Intermenstrual bleeding or metrorrhagia refers to irregularly timed episodes of bleeding 
superimposed on normal cyclical bleeding. It can be caused by: • Ovulation (physiological) • Polyps • Cervical cancer • Lower genital tract infections etc.

questions.question:
Question 11: A young girl with McCune-Albright syndrome is noted to have precocious menstruation. This 
condition is defined as the occurrence of menstruation at 
.
questions.explanation:
Precocious menstruation refers to the occurrence of menstruation before the age of 10 years. Precocious puberty in a girl is the appearance of any of the secondary sexual characteristics before 
the age of 8 years or the occurrence of menarche before the age of 10 years. McCune Albright syndrome is associated with cafe-au-lait spots, precocious puberty (and 
precocious menstruation), and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia leading to recurrent fractures. The 
image given below shows cafe-au-lait spots. 563 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: 556 
Sold by @itachibot A 45-year-old woman presents with profuse, painless vaginal bleeding. She has a history of 
6-8 weeks of amenorrhea and her UPT is negative. On ultrasound, endometrial thickness is 
21mm. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of metropathia hemorrhagica. Metropathia hemorrhagica is a form of anovulatory abnormal uterine bleeding. It is characterized 
by continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses or preceded by a 6-8 week period 
of amenorrhea. It is usually seen in the age group of 40-45 years. A history of menorrhagia may be 
present. On examination, the uterus is bulky and uniformly enlarged. Histopathological findings are: • Myohyperplasia of the uterine wall - up to 2.5cm • Thick endometrium with cystic glandular hyperplasia appearing as swiss cheese pattern • Absence of secretory endometrium i.e absence of corkscrew glands • Thin, slender endometrial polyps project into the uterine cavity • Corpus luteum is absent • One or both ovaries may contain a cyst Option A: Senile endometritis occurs after menopause when the endometrium is thin and 
atrophic. It may be associated with accumulation of pus in the uterine cavity. Option B: Halban's disease is irregular shedding and is due to persistent corpus luteum. Regular 
cycles with prolonged bleeding and normal flow is present. Option D: Endometriosis usually presents in the reproductive age group, with symptoms of 
menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain.

questions.question: Question 13: Which does 'I' stand for in the PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding?
questions.explanation:
564 
Sold by @itachibot The 'I' in the FIGO PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) stands for 
iatrogenic causes. AUB in the reproductive age group was previously known as dysfunctional uterine bleeding, 
however, that term is now obsolete. AUB can be acute or chronic: • Acute AUB - it can start sporadically or be superimposed on chronic AUB. • Chronic AUB - it lasts for 3-6 months minimum. PALM-COEIN classification of AUB: • Polyp (AUB-P): • Endometrial polyps • Endocervical polyps • Adenomyosis (AUB-A) • Leiomyoma (AUB-L). Fibroids are further classified as: • Submucosal (SM) • Other (O) • Malignancy and hyperplasia (AUB-M) • Endometrial hyperplasia • Endometrial carcinoma • Coagulopathy (AUB-C) • von Willebrand's disease • Hemophilias • Ovarian causes (AUB-O) • PCOD • Hypothyroidism • Hyperprolactinemia. • Endometrial causes (AUB-E) • Tubercular or chlamydial endometritis • Iatrogenic causes (AUB-I) • Intrauterine contraceptive devices • Anticoagulants • Tricyclic antidepressants • Not yet classified (AUB-N) includes rare causes such as • Arteriovenous malformations • Myometrial hypertrophy 565 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A 28-year-old P1L1 woman presented with heavy menstrual bleeding and occasional spotting 
between cycles. What is the first investigation to be done for her?
questions.explanation:
The first investigation to be done in a case of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) in the reproductive 
age group is urine -hCG estimation. This is done to rule out pregnancy. In the reproductive age group, anovulatory uterine bleeding is encountered less often. Therefore, 
pregnancy must be excluded. Pregnancy complications such as miscarriage, ectopic pregnancies, 
and molar pregnancies may present with AUB, hence these need to be ruled out by urine 
-hCG levels. This is done for all women in the reproductive age group. Other investigations to be done for AUB are: • Pap smear - to rule out cervical cancer and preinvasive lesions (CIN). • Transabdominal ultrasound - to visualize the pelvic organs and lesions such as endometrial 
hyperplasia, polyps, fibroids, etc. • Transvaginal ultrasound - to visualize the pelvic organs. It is done after evaluating -hCG. This is 
more comfortable for a patient compared to a transabdominal ultrasound as it doesn't require a 
full bladder.

questions.question:
Question 15: A woman with AUB-E, who was unresponsive to medical management, underwent a 
hysteroscopic ablation. Which of the following is false about this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Fertility is not preserved with ablative procedures, because the endometrium and superficial 
myometrium are destroyed. In ablative procedures, the uterus is preserved, and hysterectomy is avoided. The endometrium 
along with 2-3mm of superficial myometrium is destroyed. Various methods of endometrial ablation include: • Hysteroscopic endometrial ablation • Transcervical endometrial resection (TCRE) - now replaced by bipolar electrode called 
Versapoint • Radiofrequency induced thermal ablation (RITEA) • Microwave ablation • NovaSure - impedance-controlled endometrial ablation • Bilateral uterine artery embolization • Uterine tamponade

questions.question: Question 16: When is dilatation and curettage contraindicated?
questions.explanation:
Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is contraindicated in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) as it 
increases the risk of ascending genital infection. D&C is a minor gynecological procedure of dilating the cervix and curetting the endometrial 
tissue from the uterine cavity. Diagnostic indications of D&C include AUB, secondary 566 
Sold by @itachibot amenorrhea to detect tubercular endometritis, postmenopausal bleeding to rule out endometrial 
cancer or hyperplasia, and infertility due to genital TB. Therapeutic indications of D&C include missed abortion, incomplete abortion, retained 
products of conception, and endometrial polypectomy. Absolute contraindication of D&C includes Suspected/ desired pregnancy and lower genital 
tract infection. However, D&C is performed in some cases with genital infections like septic 
abortion (where retained pieces of placenta act as a nidus and need to be removed) and pyometra 
(as there is cervical obstruction with superinfection of menstrual blood and cellular debris, 
D&C is appropriate to remove the obstruction as well as the source of infection) Complications of D&C include ascending infection, cervical tear with bleeding, incompetent 
os, uterine perforation, and ashermann syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 31-year-old woman presented with acute abdominal pain and spotting. UPT was negative. 
On examination, she was tachycardic and afebrile. Guarding and abdominal tenderness was 
present. CT abdomen showed air in the uterine wall and pneumoperitoneum. Which of the 
following is her condition most likely to be a complication of?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of uterine perforation. In a non-pregnant uterus, uterine 
perforation is most likely to occur due to dilatation and curettage. In pregnancy and uterine malignancies, the uterus is soft. Hence, uterine perforation is 
common during surgeries. The etiology of uterine perforation is as follows: • Insertion of intrauterine contraceptive devices (IUCD)- due to the lack of provider experience. • Spontaneous migration of IUCD within the myometrium • Dilatation and curettage (D&C) • Hysteroscopy - diagnostic (e.g, hysteroscopic biopsy) or therapeutic (adhesiolysis) • Laparoscopy 567 
Sold by @itachibot It can present with fever, acute abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, and bleeding pv. Imaging 
reveals air within the uterine wall or pneumoperitoneum. The management is as follows: • Conservative management - Fundal injuries are managed conservatively, as the myometrium 
contracts around the defect. • Surgical management: • Small defects can be repaired laparoscopically or hysteroscopically. • Emergency laparotomy - as abdominal viscera may prolapse through the defect. • Hysterectomy - if the defect is large, and the patient has completed her family, hysterectomy is 
done as last resort.

questions.question:
Question 18: An 18-year-old girl presents to you with cramping abdominal pain. It starts at the onset of 
menses and is more pronounced in the first two days. Which condition is she likely suffering 
from?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of spasmodic dysmenorrhea. It presents with cramping pain 
at the onset of menses which is more pronounced in the first two days of menstruation. Dysmenorrhoea is defined as cramping pain accompanying menstruation. It can be classified as 
follows: A. Etiological classification: • Primary dysmenorrhoea - no identifiable pelvic pathology. Commonly occurs in the age group of 
18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles. • Secondary (acquired) dysmenorrhoea - is associated with pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, 
adenomyosis, PID, and endometriosis. Unilateral dysmenorrhoea can occur in a rudimentary horn of a bicornuate uterus, IUCD users, 
and cervical stenosis. B. Clinical classification: • Spasmodic dysmenorrhoea: • Most prevalent • Cramping pain at the onset of menses, more pronounced on the first 2 days. • Occurs due to myometrial contractions due to increased PGF2 • Common in adolescents and young women • Congestive dysmenorrhoea: • Pelvic pain and pelvic discomfort occurs, a few days before menses begin • Occurs due to pelvic venous congestion • Seen in pelvic endometriosis, PID, fibroids, and IUCD users • Membranous dysmenorrhoea: • Least prevalent 568 
Sold by @itachibot • The endometrium is shed as a cast at the time of menstruation • The passage of the cast is associated with painful uterine cramps

questions.question: Question 19: An increase in which of the following is spasmodic pain during dysmenorrhoea attributed to?
questions.explanation:
Spasmodic pain is attributed to myometrial contractions occuring due to increased PGF2 . This is 
secreted under the effect of progesterone. Progesterone is secreted after ovulation by the corpus luteum. Hence, in anovulatory 
cycles, menstruation is not accompanied by spasmodic pain.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 28-year-old woman presents to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of mood swings and 
depression 10 days prior to her menses. This is associated with fatigue, breast tenderness, 
and bloating. Her symptoms resolve once menses begin. What is the treatment of choice in 
this case?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD). Selective 
serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as fluoxetine, sertraline, and paroxetine are the 
treatment of choice for PMDD. DSM-5 defines premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD) as the presence of at least five of the 
associated symptoms most of the time during the premenstrual week. Symptoms improve within 
a few days after menses and are minimal in the postmenstrual period. These symptoms include: • Marked emotional lability • Marked irritability or anger • Marked depressive mood, self-deprecating thoughts • Marked anxiety • Decreased interest in activities • Difficulty in concentration • Lethargy • Appetite changes • Bloating • Breast tenderness • Weight gain Treatment of PMDD is as follows: • Lifestyle changes such as - stress reduction, adequate sleep, and exercise, reduction in caffeine 
intake, smoking cessation • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) - fluoxetine, paroxetine, sertraline • Evening primrose oil - to treat breast tenderness • Ovulation suppression - danazol, leuprolide, drospirenone • Other less proven methods - cognitive behavioral therapy, calcium supplements, etc. 569 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Premenstrual syndrome has no scientific definition. The constellation of symptoms is now 
defined under PMDD. 570 
Sold by @itachibot Uro-gynecology
